articles.title: Core Survey by NASA’s Roman Mission Will Unveil Universe’s Dark Side
articles.summary: The broadest planned survey by NASA’s upcoming Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will reveal hundreds of millions of galaxies scattered across the cosmos. After Roman launches as soon as this fall, scientists will use these sparkly beacons to study the universe’s shadowy underpinnings: dark matter and dark energy. “We set out to build the ultimate […]
articles.content:
The broadest planned survey by NASA’s upcoming Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will reveal hundreds of millions of galaxies scattered across the cosmos. After Roman launches as soon as this fall, scientists will use these sparkly beacons to study the universe’s shadowy underpinnings: dark matter and dark energy.

“We set out to build the ultimate wide-area infrared survey, and I think we accomplished that,” said Ryan Hickox, a professor at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire, and co-chair of the committee that shaped the survey’s design. “We’ll use Roman’s enormous, deep 3D images to explore the fundamental nature of the universe, including its dark side.”

This infographic describes the High-Latitude Wide-Area Survey that will be conducted by NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. This observation program will cover more than 5,000 square degrees (about 12 percent of the sky) in just under a year and a half. Scientists will use the survey to analyze hundreds of millions of galaxies scattered across the cosmos that reveal clues about the universe’s shadowy underpinnings — dark matter and dark energy — as well as a wealth of other science topics. NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center

Roman’s High-Latitude Wide-Area Survey is one of the mission’s three core observation programs. It will cover more than 5,000 square degrees (about 12 percent of the sky) in just under a year and a half. Roman will look far from the dusty plane of our Milky Way galaxy (that’s what the “high-latitude” part of the survey name means), looking up and out of the galaxy rather than through it to get the clearest view of the distant cosmos.

“This survey is going to be a spectacular map of the cosmos, the first time we have Hubble-quality imaging over a large area of the sky,” said David Weinberg, an astronomy professor at Ohio State University in Columbus, who played a major role in devising the survey. “Even a single pointing with Roman needs a whole wall of 4K televisions to display at full resolution. Displaying the whole high-latitude survey at once would take half a million 4K TVs, enough to cover 200 football fields or the cliff face of El Capitan.”

The survey will combine the powers of imaging and spectroscopy to unveil a goldmine of galaxies strewn across cosmic time. Astronomers will use the survey’s data to explore invisible dark matter, detectable only via its gravitational effects on other objects, and the nature of dark energy — a pressure that seems to be speeding up the universe’s expansion.

“Cosmic acceleration is the biggest mystery in cosmology and maybe in all of physics,” Weinberg said. “Somehow, when we get to scales of billions of light years, gravity pushes rather than pulls. The Roman wide area survey will provide critical new clues to help us solve this mystery, because it allows us to measure the history of cosmic structure and the early expansion rate much more accurately than we can today.”

Weighing shadows

Anything that has mass warps space-time, the underlying fabric of the universe. Extremely massive things like clusters of galaxies warp space-time so much that they distort the appearance of background objects — a phenomenon called gravitational lensing.

“It’s like looking through a cosmic funhouse mirror,” Hickox said. “It can smear or duplicate distant galaxies, or if the alignment is just right, it can magnify them like a natural telescope.”

This simulation shows the type of science astronomers will be able to do with future observations from NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. The sequence demonstrates how the gravity of intervening galaxy clusters and dark matter can distort the light from farther objects, warping their appearance. More intervening material creates stronger distortions. By analyzing these features, astronomers can study elusive dark matter, which can only be measured indirectly through its gravitational effects on visible matter. As a bonus, the distortion acts like a telescope, enabling observations of extremely distant galaxies. Simulations like this one help astronomers understand what Roman’s future observations could tell us about the universe, and provide useful data to validate data analysis techniques. Caltech/IPAC/R. Hurt

Roman’s view will be large and sharp enough to study this lensing effect on a small scale to see how clumps of dark matter warp the appearance of distant galaxies. Astronomers will create a detailed map of the large-scale distribution of matter — both seen and unseen — throughout the universe and fill in more of the gaps in our understanding of dark matter. Studying how structures grow over time will also help astronomers explore dark energy’s strength at various cosmic stages.

“The data analysis standards required to measure weak gravitational lensing are such that the astronomy community as a whole will benefit from very high-quality data over the full survey area, which will undoubtedly lead to unexpected discoveries,” said Olivier Doré, a senior research scientist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California, who leads a team focused on Roman imaging cosmology with the High-Latitude Wide-Area Survey. “This survey will accomplish much more than just revealing dark energy!”

While NASA’s Hubble and James Webb space telescopes both also study gravitational lensing, the breakthrough with Roman is its large field of view.

“Weak lensing distorts galaxy shapes too subtly to see in any single galaxy — it’s invisible until you do a statistical analysis,” Hickox said. “Roman will see more than a billion galaxies in this survey, and we estimate about 600 million of them will be detailed enough for Roman to study these effects. So Roman will trace the growth of structure in the universe in 3D from shortly after the big bang to today, mapping dark matter more precisely than we’ve ever done before.”

Sounding out dark energy

Roman’s wide-area survey will also gather spectra from around 20 million galaxies. Analyzing spectra helps show how the universe expanded during different cosmic eras because when an object recedes, all of the light waves we receive from it are stretched out and shifted toward redder wavelengths — a phenomenon called redshift.

By determining how quickly galaxies are receding from us, carried by the relentless expansion of space, astronomers can find out how far away they are — the more a galaxy’s spectrum is redshifted, the farther away it is. Astronomers will use this phenomenon to make a 3D map of all the galaxies measured within the survey area out to about 11.5 billion light-years away.

That will reveal frozen echoes of ancient sound waves that once rippled through the primordial cosmic sea. For most of the universe’s first half-million years, the cosmos was a dense, almost uniform sea of plasma (charged particles).

Rare, tiny clumps attracted more matter toward themselves gravitationally. But it was too hot for the material to stick together, so it rebounded. This push and pull created waves of pressure—sound — that propagated through the plasma.

This animation illustrates how small particles (in this case, sand) behave when exposed to different sound frequencies. In the very early universe, a cosmic “hum” created ripples in the primordial soup that filled space. Since the ripples were places where more matter was collected, like the rings of sand shown here, slightly more galaxies formed along them than elsewhere. As the universe expanded over billions of years, so did these structures. By comparing their size during different cosmic epochs, astronomers can trace the universe’s expansion. Nigel Stanford (used with permission)

Over time, the universe cooled and the waves ceased, essentially freezing the ripples (called baryon acoustic oscillations) in place. Since the ripples were places where more matter was collected, slightly more galaxies formed along them than elsewhere. As the universe expanded over billions of years, so did these structures.

These rings act like a ruler for the universe. Today, they are about 500 million light-years wide. Roman will precisely measure their size across cosmic time, revealing how dark energy may have evolved.

Recent results from other telescopes hint that dark energy may be shifting in strength over cosmic time. “Roman will be able to make high precision tests that should tell us whether these hints are real deviations from our current standard model or not,” said Risa Wechsler, director of Stanford University’s KIPAC (Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology) in California and co-chair of the committee that shaped the survey’s design. “Roman’s imaging survey combined with its redshift survey give us new information about the evolution of the universe — both how it expands and how structures grow with time — that will help us understand what dark energy and gravity are doing at unprecedented precision.”

Altogether, Roman will help us understand the effects of dark energy 10 times more precisely than current measurements, helping discern between the leading theories that attempt to explain why the expansion of the universe is speeding up.

Because of the way Roman will survey the universe, it will reveal everything from small, rocky objects in our outer solar system and individual stars in nearby galaxies to galaxy mergers and black holes at the cosmic frontier over 13 billion years ago.

“Roman is exciting because it covers such a wide area with the image quality only available in space,” Wechsler said. “This enables a broad range of science, from things we can anticipate studying to discoveries that we haven’t thought of yet.”

The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope is managed at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, with participation by NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California; Caltech/IPAC in Pasadena, California; the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore; and a science team comprising scientists from various research institutions. The primary industrial partners are BAE Systems Inc. in Boulder, Colorado; L3Harris Technologies in Rochester, New York; and Teledyne Scientific & Imaging in Thousand Oaks, California.

By Ashley Balzer

NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md.

articles.personality_title: NASA’s Roman Space Telescope to Map the Universe’s Dark Side in Unmatched Detail
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is preparing to launch the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, a new space observatory designed to study the universe in infrared light. Its mission includes investigating dark matter and dark energy, two mysterious components that make up most of the cosmos but cannot be seen directly.

**What happened** – Starting as soon as this fall, the Roman Space Telescope will carry out its High-Latitude Wide-Area Survey, the largest infrared survey ever planned. It will capture detailed images of more than 5,000 square degrees of the sky—about 12% of the entire sky—over roughly 18 months. This survey will observe hundreds of millions of galaxies, mapping their positions and shapes in 3D to study the effects of dark matter and dark energy.

**Impact** – This survey is unique because Roman combines a huge field of view with Hubble-quality images, allowing scientists to study gravitational lensing—how massive objects bend light—and measure cosmic expansion with great precision. By examining how galaxies cluster and move, astronomers hope to better understand why the universe’s expansion is speeding up, a puzzle linked to dark energy. Roman’s data will also help map dark matter more accurately than ever before.

**What’s next step** – After the survey begins, scientists will analyze the massive amount of data to create detailed maps of the universe’s structure over billions of years. This will test current theories about dark energy and gravity and could lead to new discoveries about how the universe works. The mission may also find unexpected phenomena, thanks to its wide and sharp view of space.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Roman Space Telescope will produce the largest, most detailed map of the universe’s galaxies to date, revealing new insights into the invisible forces shaping cosmic expansion and structure.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le télescope spatial Roman de la NASA cartographiera l’univers sombre avec un détail inégalé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA s’apprête à lancer le télescope spatial Nancy Grace Roman, un nouvel observatoire conçu pour étudier l’univers en lumière infrarouge. Sa mission inclut l’étude de la matière noire et de l’énergie noire, deux composants mystérieux qui constituent la majeure partie du cosmos mais ne peuvent pas être observés directement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Dès cet automne, le télescope Roman réalisera son enquête à grande échelle en haute latitude, la plus grande étude infrarouge jamais planifiée. Il capturera des images détaillées de plus de 5 000 degrés carrés du ciel — soit environ 12 % du ciel entier — pendant environ 18 mois. Cette enquête observera des centaines de millions de galaxies, cartographiant leurs positions et formes en 3D pour étudier les effets de la matière noire et de l’énergie noire.

**Impact** – Cette enquête est unique car Roman combine un très large champ de vision avec une qualité d’image comparable à celle du télescope Hubble, permettant aux scientifiques d’étudier le lentillage gravitationnel — comment les objets massifs déforment la lumière — et de mesurer l’expansion cosmique avec une grande précision. En examinant comment les galaxies s’assemblent et se déplacent, les astronomes espèrent mieux comprendre pourquoi l’expansion de l’univers s’accélère, un mystère lié à l’énergie noire. Les données de Roman aideront aussi à cartographier la matière noire plus précisément que jamais.

**Prochaine étape** – Après le début de l’enquête, les scientifiques analyseront la grande quantité de données pour créer des cartes détaillées de la structure de l’univers sur des milliards d’années. Cela permettra de tester les théories actuelles sur l’énergie noire et la gravité et pourrait conduire à de nouvelles découvertes sur le fonctionnement de l’univers. La mission pourrait aussi révéler des phénomènes inattendus grâce à sa large et nette vision de l’espace.

**Phrase clé** – Le télescope spatial Roman de la NASA produira la plus grande et la plus détaillée carte des galaxies de l’univers à ce jour, révélant de nouvelles informations sur les forces invisibles qui façonnent l’expansion et la structure cosmiques.
articles.personality_title_es: El telescopio espacial Roman de la NASA mapeará el lado oscuro del universo con detalle sin precedentes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA se prepara para lanzar el telescopio espacial Nancy Grace Roman, un nuevo observatorio diseñado para estudiar el universo en luz infrarroja. Su misión incluye investigar la materia oscura y la energía oscura, dos componentes misteriosos que forman la mayor parte del cosmos pero no se pueden ver directamente.

**Qué pasó** – A partir de este otoño, el telescopio Roman llevará a cabo su Encuesta de Gran Área en Alta Latitud, la mayor encuesta infrarroja jamás planificada. Capturará imágenes detalladas de más de 5,000 grados cuadrados del cielo—alrededor del 12% del cielo completo—durante aproximadamente 18 meses. Esta encuesta observará cientos de millones de galaxias, mapeando sus posiciones y formas en 3D para estudiar los efectos de la materia oscura y la energía oscura.

**Impacto** – Esta encuesta es única porque Roman combina un campo de visión enorme con imágenes de calidad similar al telescopio Hubble, permitiendo a los científicos estudiar el lente gravitacional—cómo los objetos masivos doblan la luz—y medir la expansión cósmica con gran precisión. Al examinar cómo se agrupan y mueven las galaxias, los astrónomos esperan entender mejor por qué la expansión del universo se está acelerando, un misterio vinculado a la energía oscura. Los datos de Roman también ayudarán a mapear la materia oscura con una precisión nunca antes vista.

**Próximo paso** – Después de que comience la encuesta, los científicos analizarán la enorme cantidad de datos para crear mapas detallados de la estructura del universo a lo largo de miles de millones de años. Esto pondrá a prueba las teorías actuales sobre la energía oscura y la gravedad y podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos sobre cómo funciona el universo. La misión también podría encontrar fenómenos inesperados gracias a su amplia y nítida visión del espacio.

**Frase clave** – El telescopio espacial Roman de la NASA producirá el mapa más grande y detallado de las galaxias del universo hasta la fecha, revelando nuevos conocimientos sobre las fuerzas invisibles que moldean la expansión y la estructura cósmicas.

articles.title: CubeSats’ Missions Begin
articles.summary: NASA astronaut Chris Williams pointed a camera out a window on the cupola as a set of CubeSats were deployed outside the Kibo laboratory module by a small satellite orbital deployer into Earth orbit. Students from Mexico, Italy, Thailand, Malaysia, and Japan designed the shoe-boxed satellites for a series of Earth observations and technology demonstrations. CubeSats are a class of nanosatellites – small spacecraft […]
articles.content:
NASA/Chris Williams

NASA astronaut Chris Williams pointed a camera out a window on the cupola as a set of CubeSats were deployed outside the Kibo laboratory module by a small satellite orbital deployer into Earth orbit. Students from Mexico, Italy, Thailand, Malaysia, and Japan designed the shoe-boxed satellites for a series of Earth observations and technology demonstrations.

CubeSats are a class of nanosatellites – small spacecraft weighing 1-10 kilograms – that use a standard size and form factor. The development of CubeSats has advanced into its own industry with government, industry and academia collaborating for ever increasing capabilities. CubeSats now provide a cost-effective platform for science investigations, new technology demonstrations and advanced mission concepts.

Image credit: NASA/Chris Williams
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the deployment of CubeSats designed by international students for Earth observations and technology demonstrations, highlighting a cost-effective, collaborative advancement in space technology with broad educational and scientific benefits.
articles.personality_title: International student-built CubeSats launched from the ISS for Earth studies
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – CubeSats are tiny satellites, about the size of a shoebox, that weigh between 1 and 10 kilograms. They are used for scientific research and testing new space technologies. Many countries and groups work together to build and send these small satellites into orbit because they are cheaper and easier to launch than bigger spacecraft.

**What happened** – NASA astronaut Chris Williams released several CubeSats from the International Space Station’s Kibo laboratory module. These CubeSats were designed by students from Mexico, Italy, Thailand, Malaysia, and Japan. The satellites will carry out Earth observations and test new technology while orbiting our planet.

**Impact** – This event shows how students from different countries can contribute to space exploration. Using CubeSats allows more people to take part in space science because they cost less and are simpler to build. These missions help scientists learn more about Earth and improve space technology in a way that was not possible before.

**What's next step** – The CubeSats will now begin their missions in orbit, sending back data about Earth and testing their technologies. The success of these satellites encourages more international student projects and could lead to even more advanced CubeSat missions in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Students worldwide have successfully launched small, student-designed CubeSats from the ISS to study Earth and develop new space technologies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des CubeSats conçus par des étudiants internationaux lancés depuis l’ISS pour étudier la Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les CubeSats sont de petits satellites, de la taille d’une boîte à chaussures, pesant entre 1 et 10 kilogrammes. Ils servent à la recherche scientifique et à tester de nouvelles technologies spatiales. De nombreux pays et groupes collaborent pour construire et lancer ces petits satellites en orbite, car ils sont moins coûteux et plus faciles à lancer que les grands engins spatiaux.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’astronaute de la NASA Chris Williams a déployé plusieurs CubeSats depuis le module laboratoire Kibo de la Station spatiale internationale. Ces CubeSats ont été conçus par des étudiants du Mexique, d’Italie, de Thaïlande, de Malaisie et du Japon. Les satellites vont réaliser des observations de la Terre et tester de nouvelles technologies en orbite.

**Impact** – Cet événement montre comment des étudiants de différents pays peuvent contribuer à l’exploration spatiale. Utiliser des CubeSats permet à plus de personnes de participer à la science spatiale car ils coûtent moins cher et sont plus simples à construire. Ces missions aident les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la Terre et à améliorer les technologies spatiales.

**Prochaine étape** – Les CubeSats vont commencer leurs missions en orbite, en envoyant des données sur la Terre et en testant leurs technologies. Le succès de ces satellites encourage plus de projets étudiants internationaux et pourrait conduire à des missions CubeSat encore plus avancées.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des étudiants du monde entier ont lancé avec succès de petits CubeSats conçus par eux depuis l’ISS pour étudier la Terre et développer de nouvelles technologies spatiales.
articles.personality_title_es: CubeSats diseñados por estudiantes internacionales lanzados desde la EEI para estudiar la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los CubeSats son pequeños satélites, del tamaño de una caja de zapatos, que pesan entre 1 y 10 kilogramos. Se usan para investigaciones científicas y para probar nuevas tecnologías espaciales. Muchos países y grupos trabajan juntos para construir y enviar estos pequeños satélites al espacio porque son más baratos y fáciles de lanzar que las naves más grandes.

**Qué pasó** – El astronauta de la NASA Chris Williams lanzó varios CubeSats desde el módulo laboratorio Kibo de la Estación Espacial Internacional. Estos CubeSats fueron diseñados por estudiantes de México, Italia, Tailandia, Malasia y Japón. Los satélites harán observaciones de la Tierra y probarán nuevas tecnologías mientras orbitan nuestro planeta.

**Impacto** – Este evento muestra cómo estudiantes de diferentes países pueden participar en la exploración espacial. Usar CubeSats permite que más personas formen parte de la ciencia espacial porque cuestan menos y son más fáciles de construir. Estas misiones ayudan a los científicos a aprender más sobre la Tierra y a mejorar la tecnología espacial.

**Próximo paso** – Los CubeSats comenzarán ahora sus misiones en órbita, enviando datos sobre la Tierra y probando sus tecnologías. El éxito de estos satélites anima a más proyectos internacionales de estudiantes y podría llevar a misiones CubeSat aún más avanzadas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Estudiantes de todo el mundo han lanzado con éxito pequeños CubeSats diseñados por ellos desde la EEI para estudiar la Tierra y desarrollar nuevas tecnologías espaciales.
